_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: UT Test & Contractor Maintenance on Anhydrous Ammonia System
_prev_prog_3.Description: Pawtucket Power Associates (PPA) uses anhydrous ammonia for the Inlet Cooling System that is regulated by OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations.  In 2001, PPA reviewed and updated their PSM Plan to address OSHA requirements, including a majority of the RMP Prevention Program Elements.  The major elements of the prevention program for anhydrous ammonia are summarized below:  PPA maintains documentation on the anhydrous ammonia system that provides information on the equipments' design, configuration and safe operating parameters.  The system is equipped with instrumentation that indicates potential problems.  Pressure relief valves mounted on the process vessels discharge into the header system that vents through a water deluge system and provides mitigation in the event of a release.  In March 2001, PPA updated their PSM Plan and conducted a Process Hazard Analysis (PHA), consistent with PSM requirements.  Using the "What If" technique, PPA identified potential malfunctions that could occur, along with the associated hazards, consequences,and controls.  PPA has completed the majority of the corrective actions that were identified or required as a result of the PHA.  PPA maintains proper operating procedures that describe proper start-up, shutdown, normal operating, and emergency actions.  All system operators and lead operators receive training in operating and maintenance procedures, as well as safety information at the start of their employment at the facility.  In addition, continuing on-the-job training is provided to all operators by PPA.  The competency of operators is evaluated by the observations of supervisors and communicated to employees as issues arise and during routine performance reviews.  PPA has certified that all employees currently working at the facility have the required skills, knowledge, and abilities to safely operate the system.  Operators routinely inspect process equipment and monitor system operating parameters throughout their shifts.  Storage tanks are inspected on a daily basis, and the system is inspected on an annual basis and on all system restarts by the contractor.  Preventative maintenance is conducted on an as-needed basis and each year during the facility's annual outage period.  PPA utilizes skilled outside contractors with extensive knowledge and experience with anhydrous ammonia systems to conduct inspections and maintenance whenever such activities may result in potential exposure to ammonia and prior to each system restart.  PPA has established Manangement of Change, Hot Work Permits, Employee Participation, and Contractor Safety Programs, as required by both the OSHA PSM and EPA RMP regulations.

_prev_prog_2.EquipmentTested: UT Test on Aqueous Ammonia Tank
_prev_prog_2.Description: Pawtucket Power Associates (PPA) uses aqueous ammonia in the facility's air emissions control system to reduce nitrogen oxide emissions.  The major elements of the prevention program for aqueous ammonia are summarized below:  PPA maintains documentation on the aqueous ammonia system that provides information on the equipments' design, configuration and safe operating parameters.  The system is equipped with instrumentation that indicates potential problems.  PPA conducted a Hazard Review and identified potential malfunctions that could occur, along with the associated hazards, consequences,and controls.  There were no corrective actions that were identified or required as a result of the Hazard Review.  PPA maintains proper operating procedures that describe proper start-up, shutdown, normal operating, and emergency actions.  All system operators and lead operators receive training in operating and maintenance procedures, as well as safety information at the start of their employment at the facility.  In addition, continuing on-the-job training is provided to all operators by PPA.  The competency of operators is evaluated by the observations of supervisors and communicated to employees as issues arise and during routine performance reviews.  PPA has certified that all employees currently working at the facility have the required skills, knowledge, and abilities to safely operate the system.  Operators routinely inspect process equipment and monitor system operating parameters throughout their shifts.  Storage tanks are inspected on a daily basis, and the system is inspected on a semi-annual basis and the pump is serviced annually (oil change/lubrication).  Preventative maintenance is conducted on an as-needed basis and each year during the facility's annual outage period.

_exec_summary.SummaryText: The accidental release prevention and emergency response policy at Pawtucket Power is to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local laws and regulations.  It is our goal to achieve and sustain "Zero Accident Tolerance" through effective communication, information, and training.  If an emergency were to occur, it is our procedure to notify the Pawtucket Fire Department and request that they respond to the emergency.  Pawtucket Power is a combined-cycle cogeneration power plant.  The regulated substances handled at the facility are anhydrous ammonia, used as a refrigerant to enhance gas turbine performance and efficiency, and aqueous ammonia, used as a catalyst to control nitrogen oxide (NOx) emissions.  The general accidental release prevention program at Pawtucket Power has been develped to comply with EPA's Accidental Prevention Rule, OSHA's Process Safety Management Rule, and all other applicable state and local codes and regulations.  Each system and piece of equipment at Pawtucket Power is designed, installed, and maintained in accordance with the aforementioned codes, laws, and regulations.  Pawtucket Power.  Chemical specific prevention steps for aqueous ammonia involve the use of high level alarms on the storage tank to prevent overfilling and periodic equipment inspections.  The specific prevention steps relative to anhydrous ammonia involve complete system inspections upon each re-start by a qualified firm, ammonia monitoring and detection in the vent system and equipment building, and the use of a deluge system to mitigate releases. There have been no accidents associated with ammonia during the life of the facility, through June 2004.  The emergency response program at Pawtucket Power is to contact the Pawtucket Fire Department.  It is our policy to request the Fire Department's response to an emergency and inspect the facility annually to ensure that are familiar with the facility systems and materials. nges to improve safety at Pawtucket Power, facility personnel seek opportunities to improve plant safety on an ongoing basis.
